Goodness, it’s gonna be a cooker. He moves toward the entrance of the bank. Behind him we s virtually no signs of life. It’s a miracle this bank is e open. INT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- CONT. Mr. Clauson steps through and sees:  Elsie sitting uncomfortably in the center of the lobby, propping all her weight on one arm, like a broken chair.
Elsie, you alright? She shakes her head ‘no’ as a pistol is placed to Mr. Clauson’s temple ...

A burnt field, charred and smoking, whizzes by as the eng whines. We see two men: TOBY HANSON, late 30's, a kind face marked by years of su and disappointment, rides shotgun. It’s not the face of a thief, it is the face of a farmer. Behind the wheel is TANNER HANSON, 40, his brother’s oppo in every way: mustache, shaggy hair, an air of danger tha attracts as many women as it repels. He lights a smoke as Toby wipes sweat from his brow. Tanner grins from ear to ear.
Just like the army. Doin’ more before nine a.m. than most folks do all goddam day. Toby looks straight ahead. They ride in silence for a mom Then Tanner explodes --
He pounds the dash. Toby waits for the storm to pass. It does. Silence again.
You need to go a little easier on the tellers.
I go as easy on them as they go on me. Beat.
Slow down. He doesn’t. In the distance, they see the throbbing lights of a SHERI CRUISER headed toward them.
Slow down --

I ain’t speeding. The cruiser races toward them. Tanner drives without a ca in the world. Toby is frozen to his seat, eyes tracking t car as it approaches. The cruiser whips by. Toby looks in the side mirror, cert the vehicle is going to turn around. It doesn’t.
See, little brother? We ain’t got a worry in the world. Tanner takes a long pull from his cigarette, and looks ou over the black top.
Plannin’ this and doin’ it’s two different things. Tanner laughs. His demeanor is so relaxed, you'd think th were taking a drive with no destination at all.

Shit, most people that do this don’t think to plan at all. ... You know, we're half way to Olney. Might as well put ourselves a day ahead. Toby looks exhausted. But it’s true. Tanner looks at him smiles.
C'mon. Early bird gets the worm. Beat.

Slow down.  He doesn’t. EXT. TWO LANE HIGHWAY -- CONT. The Camaro pulls away from us. We try to keep up, but it disappears over a rise. We stare at broken yellow lines a they race underneath us. CAMERA RISES. We see the Camaro in the distance. It is th only car on the road. In fact, it is the only sign of lif any direction. Smoke rises from scorched fields in every direction. This branch was built in the fifties and hasn’t had a rem since. There is one surveillance camera mounted above the teller’s counter. A MAN IN HIS 80'S is placing rolls of coins on the counte before a chubby, young TELLER. There is a dolly loaded wi three cardboard boxes beside him. They are the only two people in the bank.

I found three boxes in the barn. Lord knows how long they been sittin there. (The old man chuckles) I been living on an inmate’s diet and had all these boxes just sitting under feed sacks. The teller smiles.
How do you forget such a thing?
Old as I am, lucky I could find my way here. The teller examines a roll of pennies.
This one says 1953. She breaks open the roll.

I wonder if any of these is collector’s items. You could be sitting on a fortune here. We hear a JINGLE OF BELLS from the front door. In a flash pistol is pointed at the old man and a blurred image leap over the counter. TANNER, in ski mask, is now behind the teller, pistol to head. Toby appears beside the old man.
Open the drawer. Her eyes go wide. She raises her hands to the sky.
Put yer hands down and open the drawer. She does.
Ones, fives, tens, and twenties. No hundreds.
Don’t this figure. Good lord won't even let me have it for a damn day.
(Looking over the boxes) We don’t want your coins, old man.
So you boys is robbing the bank?
Shut up.
Keep your hands on the counter. The old man simply can’t wrap his head around what he’s seeing.
That's crazy ... Ya’ll ain’t even Mexican. She reaches for the ink pack.
No no no. Leave that where it is. And none of them in bundles, just the loose cash.
You oughta be ashamed of yerself --
Oh, I am. Make no mistake. But I’m doing it anyway. Put your hands on the counter where I can see em, old man. Got a pistol on you?
Damn right I do.
(Looks hard at Toby)Keep up with the circumstances, okay? Toby shakes his head at the scolding and frisks him, finds a snub nose .38 and sets it on the counter, out of the old man’s reach.
You gonna steal my gun?
(Pointing his pistol)I got my own gun --
We ain’t stealing from you, we’re stealing from the bank.
It’s the same thing, son. Tanner jumps the counter.
Like hell it is. They turn and run. The old man grabs shattering glass beside them as they

The brothers run around the building and the waiting Camaro. Masks removed, the brothers are drenched in sweat. They p house after house with dead lawns and no cars in the driveway. Some of the windows are broken, some boarded up. One thin certain, whoever lived in these little towns doesn’t live here anymore.
Put the gun on the counter?? You liked to get us killed!
I’m not stealing from some old man. We stealing from one place. That’s it. But Tanner isn’t angry, he’s laughing.
You're turning out to be a poor criminal. Toby opens the trash bag, judging the take. This was a mu bigger haul.

See what the early bird gets? Through the windshield we see field after field of cotton drab and stunted from the heat. Olney is far behind us no A tinge of relief on Toby’s face -- this may actually wor He leans his head back.
(The gleam returns to Tanner’s eyes) Wanna head over to the branch in Jayton? Relief gone.  10.
NO. (He looks at his brother) We hit these banks first thing in the morning. When they’re empty... That’s the last time I care to be shot at. Toby runs his hand over his sweat-drenched face.
Gotta be smart. We’re a ways from being finished.
Hell, we could do this all week.
We’re gonna. Tanner laughs.

Can’t nobody stop us ... We like the Comanches, little brother. Lords of the plains... Raiding where we please, with the whole of Texas huntin’ our shadow. Field after empty field fly by Toby’s window. He stares o over them. Tanner lights a smoke, draws in a deep drag.
Lords of the plains. That’s us ... Toby looks in the direction of his greatest worry, who exhales smoke and smiles.

INT. TEXAS RANGER’S OFFICE -- ABILENE, TEXAS -- DAY. MARCUS HAMILTON, two weeks shy of 70, thick silver mustac sits at his desk. A large Texas flag tacked to the wall behind him. He looks over a LETTER from the DPS HEADQUARTERS in Austi The heading says it all: Mandatory Retirement Referendum. The letter is worn at the edges -- Marcus has spent a fai amount of time looking it over.  11. Marcus packs a can of Copenhagen with fifty year’s worth skill, and sticks a pinch inside his lip. A younger Ranger, and by younger I mean 50, walks in. His name is ALBERTO PARKER, and aside from his olive skin, he looks almost identical to Marcus: thick mustache, beer be gold star on a starched white shirt, bone colored Stetson hat.
You hear about these bank robberies?
Why you always dress like me? Beat.
This is our uniform.
We ain’t got no uniform. You can wear any color shirt you choose. You just keep choosing mine.
Texas Ranger regs say white, blue, or tan dress shirt. Stands to reason every so often we gonna end up dressed the same.
Well, they say imitation is the greatest form of flattery, Alberto. Did you know that? Alberto is half Comanche and half Latino, though his Texa twang is as pronounced as any cowboy.
Wanna hear about these bank robberies or just sit there and let Alzheimer’s run its course?
Where at?
First Texas in Archer City and First Texas in Olney.
FBI looking for an assist?  12.
Ain’t theirs. First Texas ain’t got branches outside the state. Not interstate commerce. A flicker of fire ignites in Marcus’s eyes.
You may get to have some fun before they send you to the rocking chair yet. Marcus’s chair squeaks as he leans back.
+. I may have one hunt left in me.

The Camaro throws dust along the dirt road as it drives p a rotting house, various outbuildings, and a collapsing b A few skinny cattle try to eek out a meal from the dead grass. The Camaro drives past the barn, past a dried pond, and stops. Toby steps out of the Camaro. Climbs on a FRONT-END LOADE bulldozer in layman’s terms). Tanner drives the Camaro in ten-foot deep ditch. We look down on the blade holding two tons of dirt. Watch it releases the load, pounding the roof of the Camaro. We see Tanner carrying two duffels and the trash bags of money toward the sheet metal barn. Half-starved cattle watch with curiosity from the relativ shade of a mesquite tree.  13. EXT. SHEET METAL BARN -- CONT. Tanner pulls open the doors to the barn. Inside, we see T VEHICLES. A Chevy Blazer, an old Ford Taurus, and a ruste Ford pick up. Tanner tosses the duffels on the hood of the Taurus. Walk out of the barn carrying the bags of money. EXT. FRONT PORCH -- HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- A LITTLE LATER. Tanner sits, guzzling a beer, an unopened Bud in his lap. Toby walks up, Tanner tosses the beer to him.
I need you sober.
Who the hell gets drunk off beer?
You count it? Tanner smiles.
Ain’t my money. Toby begins stacking and counting the cash as he sips his beer.
We oughta go hit the branch in Coleman before we change this money.
We change the money first. Hit the branch in Coleman in the morning.
It don’t make no sense to drive to Oklahoma, then drive all the way back to Coleman, then all the way back to Oklahoma when we could change all the money tonight.
It don’t make sense to you.
That’s what I said.  14. But Toby offers no explanation.
Goddam that was fun ... Wasn’t it?
No. Tanner laughs out loud.

You lying bastard. I saw you. You liked it ... looked like you were sproutin’ a little wood fer that teller in Olney too. That’s the problem with these baggy jeans -- can’t hide a hard hog against yer leg. Remind me to wear my wranglers if we start robbin’ high schools. Toby looks up.
This ain’t supposed to be fun. And we ain’t robbing anybody. We’re robbing ‘em back. Tanner drains his beer, cracks open another.
Call it what you want. It’s the most fun I’ve had with clothes on. I wouldn’t have missed this fer the world and two hookers. Toby looks at the stacks of money.

Half way there. Tanner holds out a beer. Toby looks into his smiling eyes Shakes his head and takes it anyway. Tanner walks to the edge of the porch. Jumps off. Walks o and turns back toward the house.
Boy this place looks like shit. Tanner looks over the emaciated cattle in the field besid him.  15.

Ain't a decent steak between the whole lot of those sorry sons of bitches. Toby watches his brother, senses the storm brewing. Knows silence is the best weapon against it. Tanner shakes his head at the crumbling house. For the fi time, he isn’t smiling. He jumps back on the porch and wa inside. Toby rubs his sunburned temples, sighs, then stands and follows. INT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- CONT. Toby comes through the front door. The furniture is at le thirty years old. Boxes are stacked everywhere. We see a SUIT laying across a chair at the dining room ta On the table is a PAMPHLET from a funeral -- black and wh photo of an old woman on the front. The color version of that photo hangs on the wall. Beside the pamphlet is a FIRST TAXES BANK folder with numerous loan papers sprawled around it. Tanner steps out from the kitchen. Looks around.
You haven't done much cleaning.
Cleaned mama six times a day. That was enough for me. Tanner picks up the funeral pamphlet.
She died in the bedroom?

Yeah. Tanner takes off down the hall. After a moment, Toby foll  16. INT. BEDROOM -- CONT. A HOSPICE BED, complete with rails, sits in the center of room, An IV stand by its side. The sheets and blankets ar crumpled and tossed back, as if someone just climbed out.
Better get this out of here before your boys move in.
It’s on the list. Tanner sips his beer. Looks around the room. Stacks of magazines. Countless prescription bottles on the dresser.
She was in this bed a while, huh?
Three months. Tanner nods. Shuffles his feet. Guilt setting in.
I could've lent a hand if she'd asked. Could’ve fed them skinny cows at least.
Got nothing to feed ‘em.
Well, could’ve cleaned up this house a bit. Toby almost smiles.
Never thought of you as the go-to guy for house cleaning.
No ... Just robbing banks. Beat.
Hey bud, your phone dials out, you could have checked on us anytime.
She could’ve asked.  17. Tanner finishes his beer, crushes the can, and tosses it the bed.

Fuck her. She never wanted nothing to do with me anyway. Tanner walks out of the room, brushing past Toby. Toby looks at the beer can. He walks over, picks it up, a puts it on the night stand. EXT. RANCH HOUSE -- MOMENT LATER. Toby steps onto the porch. Finds Tanner leaning against a old corral fence. Toby gives his brother some distance.
She leave a will? Beat.
Yeah.
Was I in it? Silence. Tanner turns to his brother, who looks down at h boots, then dead into Tanner’s eyes.
No. Tanner has to smile. Drinks from yet another beer. Toby s off the porch and walks up beside him.
The will don’t matter. She left everything to me, and by Friday, it all goes to my boys ... She didn’t mean nuthin’ by it. Mama’s been gone for years. I just tended to the body.
She damn sure meant it. Mama was like a dog that got kicked every time it was fed. (MORE )
After a while she started to think the beatin’ was part of the meal. Hated me fer knowin’ the difference.
That’s not it.
No?
It’s cuz you never understood that fighting back just makes the beating last longer. Tanner laughs. So does Toby. A little.
Oh, I understood it. Tanner leans into Toby, resting his hand on his brother's neck.
That's why I stopped fighting and shot that son of a bitch. They both lean on the fence, looking out over the parched field filled with mesquites -- the only plant mean enough survive in this place.

EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -—- ARCHER CITY, TX -- DAY. Marcus and PARKER pull up to as large a crowd as Archer C can muster: a dozen people and another dozen Sheriff's deputies stand under the awning of the bank, hiding from sun like bats. They walk toward the ‘crowd’ as a truck pulling a horse trailer slows. The window rolls down and we see a RANCHER 50, his face as weathered as it is unforgiving.
What’s gong on?
Somebody robbed the bank this morning.  19.
Do what?
Ain’t seen no one unusual in town, have you?
I don’t come to town except to buy diesel and put my paycheck in that sombitch right there ( points at the bank), and you say someone robbed it?
Looks that way. The rancher shakes his head.
There was a time you could have left that bank unlocked overnight and no one steal a penny. Marcus smiles.
I remember it. (Hands him a card) You see anyone that looks a little sideways, you give me a call.
Sideways don’t want to meet me. Find itself on the wrong end of a short rope.
Well, that would simplify things for everyone but you.
Maybe. If you can find the tree. The rancher pulls away. Marcus smiles.
God, I love West Texas. They walk to the bank as a DEPUTY approaches.
Weren’t much of a robbery. Got off with just under seven thousand. (MORE )
Took the drawer money. Twenty’s and under. Only loose bills.
So no ink pack.
Nope. Marcus nods.
Smart.
That was smart, wasn’t it. Can we get a look at the video? The deputy’s eyes narrow.
Let me introduce you to the bank manager. Waves them over to a boiling Mr. Clauson.
Why can’t we wait inside? It’s gotta be -- He looks above them to the First Texas sign and thermomet MR. CLAUSON (CONT’D) My goodness gracious, it’s a hundred and five and barely noon.
It’s a crime scene, Mr. Clauson.
Can we get a look at the surveillance video? Mr. Clauson shrinks a little.
Well, umm... They all wait for him to continue. He doesn’t. Just looks them, sweating.
No video.  21.
«+. No video? Marcus looks up and points to the surveillance camera abo the front door.
What's that?
Oh, we got cameras, but ... They wait for him to finish the sentence. He doesn’t.
VCR busted, is that it?
They been planning to switch us over to a digital system that feeds right into the computer, these new cameras, they don’t hook to our VCR's. Need some kind of USB port.
Mmhmm. Turns to PARKER.

Call over to the Young County Sheriff's, see if they just hit teller drawers and stuck to small bills, I’m sure they did, but -- and ask em if they thought to hook their cameras to some sort of recording device. PARKER dials his cell. Marcus turns to Mr. Clauson.
They armed?
Yes sir. Pistols.
Faces was covered?
Ski masks, long shirts, sweat shirts and baggy pants, like them thugs in Dallas.  22.
Tweakers maybe?
Maybe.
Little early in the morning for tweakers --
What the hell you talking about? Tweakers don’t sleep at all. They just ... Tweak. All day and all night. And think of ways to tweak some more -- like robbing banks.
These boys ain’t tweakers. Tweakers rob drug stores and parked cars, not banks. Marcus spots Elsie, sitting on the steps, sweating bucket He walks to her.
You the teller? She looks up at him. Her face wearing the violation of th morning.
They pushed me to the ground. Gun to my face. Made me sit on the floor. Her face curls at the thought.
On the damn floor.
I know their faces was covered but could you tell their race? She just looks at him.
Black? White?
Their skin or their souls?  Beat. 23.
Let’s leave their souls out of it for now.
If it was two black men, they’d have never made it IN the bank ...
So they appeared Caucasian is what you're saying.
(Nodding) From around here somewhere is my guess. From their voices. PARKER walks up.
Young County says same deal.
They got video? PARKER shakes his head.
Same deal all the way around.
Doesn’t Wal-Mart sell all sorts of electronics? My word ... These boys ain't done, I’1l tell you that much.
How come?

They're patient. Just hit the drawers and don’t take the hundreds cuz that’s the bank’s money -- you can trace that. They’re trying to raise a certain amount is my guess and it’s gonna take a few banks to get there at this rate. Besides ... Marcus looks at Mr. Clauson, Elsie, and the little bank.

This is just too damn easy.  24. Marcus looks back over the small crowd -- all simple, cou folk, milling about in a state of grave disbelief. It’s a miracle people haven’t been robbing them non-stop for the past century.

Toby and Tanner sit at a table scarfing chicken fried ste Through the window we see a WEST TEXAS STATE BANK branch. They are no longer dressed in baggy, urban gangster wear, like the poor country boys they are. Aside from a few old timers sipping coffee in a distant booth, the diner is empty.
You're boys know how rich they’re about to be?
They don’t know anything.
You take ‘em to the funeral? A beat as they chew their food.
Like I said. They don’t know anything.
You haven’t told ‘em their grandmama died? (Toby just eats) When’s the last time you saw ‘em? Beat.
When we all went to the rodeo in Stamford. Right after you got out. Tanner stops chewing.
That was last year. And that'll do it for Toby’s appetite. He sets his fork d  25.
I talk to ‘em on the phone. When Debbie’s not around ... It’s like time hooked a chain to ‘em, and it’s just ... pulling them away.
Want a little advice?
No.
Go see ‘em tomorrow. In case this don’t work out, at least they’1l have a chance to do something if we get popped -- lord knows your spider of an ex-wife won’t let this go without a fight.

Got any idea how much I owe in child support? Debbie sees me walking up, she’ll have the sheriff on the phone before I ring the doorbell. When we’re done with this, I’1l see ‘em every day. Tanner laughs at his brother. Beat.
You got enough in your front pocket to fix that problem.
We'd have to add one to the list.
So add one. Toby looks at his plate.
You talk like we ain’t gonna get away with this. Tanner leans into him.
I ain’t never met nobody who got away with anything. Ever. Have you?  26. Tanner smiles. Wipes his mouth with his napkin and tosses on his plate.
I gotta shit like an old goat. Grab the check and meet me out front. And Tanner’s off. Toby swirls his almost empty tea, watching the few remain ice cubes travel around the bottom of the cup.

Boy, if that ain’t a hint, I don’t know what is. We look up at JENNY ANN, 29, a real looker when she was a teenager. Now, too plump to be called pretty, but still c and proudly displaying the one benefit of gaining fifty pounds. Her blouse can barely contain her breasts. She takes his cup and fills it. JENNY ANN (CONT’D) You like your steak?
I did.
(Looking over his plate) Got a ways to go yet.

You'll be here all night waiting for me to finish this. She stands over him, smiling. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- CONT. A young teller, this must be her summer job because she l sixteen, sits at her ‘window’ staring at a small black an white TV.
Sure is quiet in here.
Everyone’s at lunch, can I -- A ski mask stares back, pistol casually pointed at her.  27.
Open that drawer and take out the fives, tens, and twentys. Fan em out in front of me like a deck of cards. She does as he says. Looks at him, almost hyperventilatin
Your purse down there?
I don’t have any money.
Don’t want your money, darlin’. He smiles a toothy grin through the mask.
I want your driver’s license. Hand it over. She fumbles for her purse, retrieves it. Hands him the license.
What are you gonna do?
Depends. If you call the police -- Tanner looks over his shoulder to a glass office, a man sitting behind the desk, facing away from us.
Or say anything to him, (He holds up the license) I’m gonna drive to your house and kill everyone I find. Understand? She frantically nods ‘yes’.
Good girl. He smiles, his eyes lingering over her young body, watchi her breasts heave with every panicked breath.
You’re lucky I’m on a schedule. He turns and walks out. The girl leans back on her stool, gasping for air.  28. INT. DINER -- CONT.
What do you do?
(He lies) Last job was for a natural gas company.
That sounds high dollar. He smiles.
Nothing high dollar about drilling, and ... No one’s drilling for gas now anyway.
Well, they’re sure drilling for oil. Ain’t one drill the same as the next? He looks at her bright eyes and eager, almost flirty smil It makes him a little uncomfortable.
That's my take on it. Now I just gotta convince someone else to believe me.
I believe you.

Just a thought. She stands there. He says nothing. Her coyness leaves her Only desperation remains. Finally, she walks off.  He looks at the bill: $18.49 29. He looks in her direction, pulls a wad of stolen money fr his pocket and counts out two hundred in twenties. EXT. DINER -- VERNON, TEXAS -- CONTINUOUS. Toby walks to the Taurus and looks up to see Tanner RUNNI toward him.
Start the car. Toby puts it together.
Shit. He jumps in the car and fires it up. Tanner jumps INT. TAURUS -- CONT. Toby heads straight for the side streets.
WHAT DID I TELL YOU!!! YOU’RE GONNA GET US KILLED!!! THAT’S NOT A FIRST TEXAS BRANCH ... I must be out of my goddam mind to ask for your help on this. Tanner holds up a wad of cash.
Bet you don’t owe this much in child support. in. He doesn’t. Toby collapses his head against the seat.
You just put us a goddam day behind. Tanner lights a cigarette. Smiles.
You’re welcome. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- A FEW MOMENTS LATER. The bank manager walks toward the teller, his head in a f  30.

I need these copied in triplicate before we lock up -- He looks up to see the terrified girl, mascara running do her cheeks, shaking. He leans over the counter and sees t open, almost empty drawer. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) Did you hit the alarm? She just shivers. The manager leans his body over the counter and reaches h hand underneath, hitting a white button. The teller screa for all she’s worth and claws at his hands --
INT. MARCUS’S LINCOLN -- LATE AFTERNOON. Marcus’s cell phone rings. He hands it to PARKER.
Can’t answer your own phone?
I’m driving, all your doin’ is twiddling your fat fingers.

Ranger Hamilton's phone (Listens, then looks at Marcus) Turn around. EXT. COUNTRY ROAD -- CONT. We watch as Marcus’s Lincoln whips around, heading back north... EXT. HANSON RANCH -- SUNSET. We watch Toby plant peach trees in the red dirt that now rests on the Taurus. Tanner sips a beer, standing under t shade of a large mesquite.
That one looks crooked, Toby. Could be a dead giveaway.  31. Tanner chuckles at his own joke. Toby marches toward the house.
Now we won’t make it to Lawton till damn near midnight and we have to stay over cuz we gotta get another goddam car first thing tomorrow.

I‘ll still be drinking first thing tomorrow. How bout third thing? Toby storms off toward the house. Tanner empties his beer Tosses it on the ground, still laughing at his own joke a cracks open another. His smile disappears. With no one watching, his bravado leaves him too. He no longer looks dangerous. Just lonely ...
INT. MARCUS’S LINCOLN -- SUNSET. Marcus and PARKER head north on a two lane black top. Emptiness on either side of them.
Just over an hour between the first two, then wait all day to hit the bank in Vernon... Boy that’s bold, driving all over in a car with stolen money.
It’s reckless is what it is. Tweakers, I’m telling you.
I don’t think these boys is reckless. Damn sure ain’t tweakers. They know exactly what they’re doing. PARKER studies his partner.
How in the world are you gonna survive without someone to out smart? You need a hobby and quick ... How bout a horse?  32.
Beth was the rider. A horse would just remind me of her. Beat.
You like to fish?
Not enough to do it every goddam day.

When I retire, I’m gonna move Esma and me to Galveston, and buy a fishing boat -- There’s these boats got a bedroom, kitchen, bathroom, everything. Like a floating apartment. Live on that sombitch right at the pier.
Guess you forgot about the hurricane that washed away the pier and the rest of Galveston with it.
They're gonna rebuild it. I ain’t retiring next week, you are. The words stung more than either men expected. PARKER fum idly with the seat belt while Marcus stares straight ahea
Who knows, maybe one of these bank robbers will want a gun fight, and I'll dodge retirement in a blaze of glory.
I seen you shoot. There won’t be much glory in it. Marcus laughs.
Well, I’m lucky I got a half breed by my side to avenge me ... If you can stay sober enough to do it, knowing how you injuns like the bottle. PARKER laughs at the insult.  33.

I’d chase them all the way to hell and kill ‘em on the devil’s doorstep ... Take my damnation with a smile, my friend. We look out the windshield. Black smoke blocks out the setting sun.

What in the hell is that? The road winds up a hill. They crest it and see: CATTLE, HUNDREDS OF THEM, STANDING IN THE ROAD. Marcus locks the brakes. The Lincoln slides and squeals t stop. They sit in silence, surrounded by cattle.
Good Lord, Marcus. COWBOYS on horseback race through the cattle, dismount, a frantically cut the barbed wire on the fence along the fa side of the road. Marcus leans out his window.
Hey, ya’ll burning this field?

Why in the shit would we do that?? This kicked up along the highway. Wind keeps turning, goddam if it ain’t been chasing us for miles. Whichever way we go, this damn fire follows. The cowboy is on his horse and riding up toward Marcus’s window.
Wish we could do something for you.  34.

It’ll burn out when it hits the Brazos. No one to call around here anyway. These boys is on their own. The cattle pass, cowboys whooping and hollering behind th Marcus starts the car down the road, which is now covered cow shit. Marcus crests the rise in the road and the fire comes int view -- a vast expanse of smoldering black earth in its w ... Across the road, coyotes, one after the other, trot across the road. If the Arc never showed.
Slow down. Marcus looks at him cross-eyed.
You see that fire to the left of us?  35.

There’s animals all over the damn road and you’re -- The car jerks to a stop. Standing in the middle of the road in the headlights is a cougar. It looks at them like a man caught on the toilet. As the dull orange of the setting sun disappears, the neo orange of the fire bleeds toward them like lava. Two more deer trot across the road. Through the headlight an exodus of dozens of rabbits.
This is the craziest thing I ever seen.
What a day.
Tanner drives as Toby rides shotgun. Country music keeps company. The air between them is thick. Tanner slows and turns onto a dirt road.
What are you doing? We’re a day behind as it is.  36.

Casino ain't going nowhere. I need a few things (Off Toby’s look). My trailer’s right up here. Toby stews as the Blazer bounces down the dirt road. They turn onto an easement and come to a bump gate -- a spring mounted gate one bumps with the grill of a car, forcing the gate to open and very slowly close as a vehic passes through. Whose land is this?

Jeremy Chalker’s. Let’s me keep it here in exchange for killing coyotes. And any poachers who should wander this way. Tanner winks at him. They bounce past mesquites and junip and come to a tattered trailer. It is missing a rear whee the axle propped level with stacked wood. It is faded and filthy. A portable generator sits beside as do propane tanks and gas cans. The Blazer stops. Tanner hops out.

Come on in. Tanner disappears into the trailer. INT. TRAILER -- CONT. Toby steps into the ‘living area’. It is absolutely filth Clothes, fast food bags, empty beer cans everywhere. Toby almost holds his nose as he looks around.

There’s cold beer in the fridge. Toby goes to the fridge and grabs one. Anything to beat t stifling heat, made worse by standing in this tin box.  37. Toby notices a shelf that runs just beneath the ceiling. it are framed photos of them as boys, as teenagers, as yo men. They are the only things that are not broken or in disarray. He moves closer. Looks at them. One in particular: Tanner Toby on the front porch of the ranch house with their mot - her cold, unforgiving gaze, tempered by Toby's expressionless face, and Tanner -- all smiles. Toby looks at it, his face now washed with regret.
She looks meaner’n hell in that one, don’t she?
Don’t look happy. Tanner grins his devil grin.
That's cuz I was standing next to her. Grab this for me, will you? He hands a duffel bag to Toby. The weight of it jerks Tob arm down.

Toss it in the truck, I'll be right out. Toby exits and Tanner opens a small closet door, grabs an 15 assault rifle, and a scoped 30-06 ... EXT. TANNER’S TRAILER -- CONT. Toby tosses the bag in the back. Unzips it: ammo cans. Tanner walks out of the trailer carrying two rifle cases.
We don’t need those.
They're my livelihood. Can’t just leave ‘em in the trailer for days on end.
Who’s gonna find ‘em out here?  38.

No one now. Tanner places them in the back then climbs in the driver' seat. Toby turns and looks at the trailer -- This is how his brother lives. All he has to show for for two years of life. Toby shakes his head, all anger gone. in its place. He climbs in the Blazer, looks at his brother.
What?
Nothing. It’s the kindest we’ve heard Toby speak. EXT. GAS STATION -- HIGHWAY -- LATER. Tanner rests his feet on the dash while Toby pumps gas. T filled, Toby hangs up the pump.
You want anything?

Winston lights and a Dr. Pepper. Toby walks off. A NEW DODGE CHALLENGER, Painted to look vaguely like the Dukes of Hazard vehicle, pulls up in all soulless pretension. Behind the wheel is the post-modern version of white tras in his 20’s: head shaved, MMA tank top, and a mountain of attitude. How this dickhead afforded this car in the first place is mystery. Tanner looks over at him. The young punk stares back.
What? Tanner smirks. Looks away.
What old man?  39. Tanner looks back at the steroid assisted build of this asshole, and his skinny buddy riding shotgun.
You looking for trouble, you came to the right place, mother fucker. Tanner turns lazily toward him, locks eyes.
Boy, you'd think there was ten of me.
Oh yeah? The punk flashes a pistol.

Not so fucking tough now, are you? The punk is stepping out when the car door is SLAMMED bac into him. The gun falls to the ground. Toby grabs the punk by his ears and pulls him halfway out window, then proceeds to pound his face with elbow after elbow. He does it with a speed and violence we did not ex of him. Tanner watches with a combination of amusement and affect Toby steps over to the passenger door while the punk hang unconscious from the driver's window. When Toby throws open the passenger door, he is met with raised hands and a look of terror.
He had it coming! He had it coming! Toby slams the door and walks toward the Blazer. Tanner l back, feet still on the dash.
Look at you, got a little spunk left in you yet. Toby bends over and picks up the pistol.
And even remembered the gun. You’re becoming an old hand at this.  40.
This asshole could have killed you. Tanner smiles and casually raises his own pistol.
Not the way it would've gone, little brother. Toby climbs in the passenger seat. Tanner starts the engi as the punk slowly comes to and looks up at Tanner, his broken nose bleeding profusely.

Ten of me. I told you. Tanner slams the Blazer in gear and they pull back on the road. INT. WEST TEXAS STATE BANK -- NIGHT. The teller is being comforted by two of her friends. A fe VERNON PD OFFICERS mill about. One receives a radio call. listens then approaches the teller.
There’s an officer with your mama right now, she’s fine. You’re daddy’s on his way here. Marcus and PARKER push through the bank door. The officer spots them and moves in their direction.

She's a little shook up. Perp took her driver's license. Threatened her family if she talked to us. Had a hell of a time finding them. Mama works in Wichita Falls and her daddy works on the Waggoner ranch.
That a fact. They reach the girl.
What’s your name, young lady?
Natalie. Martinez.
There’s gonna be officers watching your house extra careful till we catch these buggers, I give you my word.
There’s more than one??
«+. Only one man robbed the bank? She nods yes.
Dressed like a cowpoke, ‘cept for the ski mask.
Gloves?
Like a surgeon wears.
Other waiting in the car, maybe?
That's not the way they been doing it. Why change what works?
He ran to a car parked out front of the cafe. They both turn.
You saw the car? She nods again.
Green, four doors.
How old? Late model --
I don’t know cars, mister.
Was it a nice car, an okay car, or a real piece of shit?  42. She looks him dead in the eye.
A real piece of shit.
Now we're getting somewhere. (Turns and sees the bank manager) That looks like a man who could foreclose on a house. Walks up to him.
You the bank manager?
Yessir, I am.
Didn't happen to have your surveillance cameras on this morning, did you?
Of course. Beat.
So you got the robbery on video.
Of course we do. What kind of bank would we be if we didn’t have video surveillance?
First Texas Bank. (Turns to PARKER and winks) We have video. Care to give it a watch while I wander over to the cafe?
Would you order me something while you're there? I’m starving.
I doubt they serve pemmican. PARKER has had enough.
You know, I’m half Mexican too.  43.
I’1ll get to that when I’m out of Indian insults. But it’s gonna be a while. Marcus turns and walks out.
You Rangers are an odd bunch.

No. Just him. INT. DINER -- VERNON, TEXAS -- NIGHT. Marcus steps through the door. The group of old men still sitting in the corner, waitresses peering through the win blinds at the activity across the street.
Evening.
Howdy.
I guess you’re aware of the doings at the bank.
I did notice.
Any out-of-towners come through today? The waitress nods.
Jenny Ann waited on a couple of old boys that ain’t from here.
And where could I find Jenny Ann?
She's in the back. I’1l go get her. She disappears into the kitchen. Marcus turns to the old He knows the answer to his question before he asks --
Ya'll been here for a while?
Long enough to watch someone rob the bank that’s been robbing me for thirty years.
You say you saw them?
Saw the guy running from the bank.
What’d he look like?
Had a mask on. But he ran pretty good, so I'd gather he’s youngish.
That so ... What’s youngish in your book?
Younger’n you and me, but older than all these little girls running around here pouring tea. Pretty sure they was sitting right over there, having lunch.
That a fact. Can you describe them any better than youngish?

Tall, both of ‘em. Lean, like cowboys. Looked like brothers if you ask me. One had a mustache and scruff, other one was clean shaved. Scruffy one looked like trouble. Other one just looked like a old country boy. Jenny Ann walks up to him. Looks at his badge.
Texas Ranger?
Yes ma’am. Tell me bout these handsome young strangers you waited on.
Who said handsome?  Beat. 45.
I did. Based on the fact you didn’t meet me in the parking lot hollering about the two out of towners eating here right before a bank robbery.
They never mentioned they was robbing the bank.
Pay cash for their dinner?
That a crime now?
How much they leave?
How much.
Two hundred dollars.
Can I see the bills they paid with?
Not a chance in hell.
That’s evidence.

It’s evidence if they’re the bank robbers. Till then it’s my tip. Her eyes grow fierce. JENNY ANN (CONT’D) And half my mortgage. So you go get a warrant and come after the money I'll be using to keep a roof over my daughter’s head. She turns and shakes her big ass back to the kitchen. The men laugh.
She's a tiger, that one.  PARKER comes through the door.
Just one man hit the bank, like she said. Checkered button down shirt. Jeans. Ski mask. That’s about all the video tells us. Marcus looks over at the old timer.
Yep. Checkered shirt. That’s him.
(Pointing to the table by the window) They was eatin’ right over there. Tipped her two hundred dollars. Marcus smiles as he looks toward the kitchen.
Go wrestle a description from the sassy fat girl in the kitchen. And get that tip from her. We’re gonna check them bills.
(To PARKER) Good luck.
Yeah, I’d expect some resistance .-. And call that Best Western on 287 and grab us a room.
We're stayin’ the night? Marcus smiles.
This is where all the action is. PARKER shakes his head and moves toward the kitchen.

Sure seems foolish ... The days of robbing banks and living to spend the money’s long gone, ain’t they? ... Long gone for sure. 46.  47. His friends nod in agreement, almost sadly. Marcus looks over, knowing they will be dead in a few years -- knowing and dominos and death is his future too.
Toby drives, Tanner is sprawled out in the front seat. Ye lines race underneath the hood in the dim glow of the headlights.
What does Justin want to do when he’s grown?
Right now he’s just focusing on slinging a football for A&M.
That’s what did me in.
He’s a lot like you.
Bet that puckers yer red eye. Toby smiles.
More than you know.
Forty two years of life, ten of em in prison ... If he’ll just turn left where I turned right, he’1l be okay. George Strait comes through the speakers.
“COLD FORT WORTH BEER, JUST AIN'T
Tanner leans into him, close to his ear.
“I TRIED IT NIGHT AFTER NIGHT.”  48. Toby tries to suppress a grin. Beat.
If you don’t think we can get away with this, why’d you agree to do it? Tanner lights a cigarette. Cracks the window.

Cuz you asked, little brother. Toby looks at Tanner -- a living testament to self destruction -- and absorbs both the simplicity and weight the statement. The neon lights of THE COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO invade t night sky and flood the road with yellows, reds, and gree Tanner comes to life at the sight.
My God that’s pretty. How we entertained ourselves before they let Indians open casinos, I'll never know.
Just ... We’re here to change the money, not lose everything at the blackjack table.
Blackjack’s for old women. I’11l leave that to you -- hold ‘em, baby. TEXAS HOLD ‘EM YOU SONS OF
Toby can’t help but smile as the virus of Tanner’s excite invades him...
The chimes of slot machines fills the air as does the ene of people desperate to win what they can’t earn. Toby and Tanner stand in line to check in. Tanner is almo childlike with anticipation.
Get drunk with me.
I’m not gettin’ drunk --

We’re gonna remember this forever, Toby. Tanner smiles like a child.

We do not -- dear lord, look at you --(Pretends to adjust a neck tie) we would be obliged if you would provide us accommodations, though we failed to call ahead. The clerk smiles.
He’s gonna be feisty, isn’t he?
That’s one way of putting it. There is a stack of books displayed at the check in. A bl and white photo of the great Comanche Chief QUANAH PARKER the cover. Tanner notices and points to the title --
Lords of the Plains. Tanner grabs a copy.  50.
We'll take this too. You Comanche?

We just need a, umm ... credit card for incidentals and if you could fill out these... She hands them room forms.

Let’s get another shot... They’1l be pretty soon enough. BARTENDER!
Shots are poured. Tanner grabs his and raises it.
To your boys. And the future we’re giving ‘em. Toby reluctantly raises his glass. Tanner touches his to Toby’s. Then slams it back.
Let’s change this money and have some fun.

And how old is Tinkerbell? Beat.
I don’t umm ... I don’t know. Old, like eight or something.  52.

Cuz they ain’t robbing banks in Abilene.

Tinkerbell.
You mind if I change the channel before my head explodes? Marcus and PARKER lay in separate queen beds, wearing the undershirts and staring at the boob box.
Sure. PARKER surfs. Finds PAT ROBERTSON screaming about Obama a Satan. One in the same, based on Pat’s diatribe. MARCUS (CONT’D) We ain’t gonna watch this, are we?
Ain’t you Christian?
I am, but I ain’t stupid. God doesn’t talk through this man any more than he does through my dog.
Then maybe you should give your dog a listen.
Ain’t you Indian? You’re supposed to be burning sage and dancing around the bed whooping like a bee stung you.
I’m Catholic.  53.
I'd rather dance around a fire with a spear -- hell, I’d rather you stab me with a spear than watch this. Change the channel.
I'd like a little God in my ears before I go to sleep --
Then open the window and listen to the wind. PARKER changes the channel to ESPN.
Happy? They are replaying highlights from the University of Texa first game of the year.
This is what God watches. PARKER clouds.
Don’t worry, they’ll have soccer highlights soon enough. That’s for your Mexican half. PARKER turns from the TV. Buries his head in his pillow. Marcus is glued to the tube.
Look at that boy run. Longhorns gonna have a good team this year. I’ll never understand that soccer. Anything a five year old can do ain't a sport. PARKER shifts in the bed.

Who invented soccer, the Aztecs? Kicking around skulls or something? That sounds like a Comanche sport. PARKER tosses the remote in Marcus’s general direction. Marcus grabs it and cradles it like an egg. Victorious.  54.
In three weeks you can watch TV all day.
You know what’s funny, Alberto? Beat.
... What.
In a year’s time, it’s my teasing you'll miss. It’s what you’ll laugh about when you stand over my grave and wish me well.
God, I hope that’s tomorrow. Marcus gives a hearty laugh.
That’s a good one. You’ll get the hang of this yet. PARKER pulls the covers up higher, trying like hell not t like this old bastard.
Toby counts out one, two, three, four, five thousand doll in twenties and tens. He looks at the window teller and lies.

We take it any way you bring it, mister. She takes the money, puts it in a money counter, and slid him ten thousand dollars in chips. WINDOW TELLER (CONT’D) (Knowing it won’t help) Good luck.  55. They walk from the window. Toby hands his brother a chip tray.
Just like that. No trace. Don’t lose it all.
Take your own advice.

You wanna come to the poker table? Can’t no one lose money at poker, not even you.
I’m gonna watch the Aggie game and have a beer.

Suit yerself. And Tanner’s off. Toby looks around. He heads to the bar. Orders a beer and looks out over the casino. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- POKER TABLE -- NIGHT. A winner ... INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- BAR -- NIGHT. Toby sits at the bar, watching a football game. Beside hi sits a woman, clearly a hooker, though a decent looking o  56. Quite a stack. Toby looks over at her. It’s clear what she is, but she Manages to make that part of her appeal.
Yeah, been pretty lucky. She slides closer.
No. When lucky men win, they hurry home like a scalded dog. Men that can gamble and keep their money ... That’s a smart man. He looks her in the eye.
Not much of a character study, are you?
Sweetheart, studying character’s my profession.
That's not the profession I was figuring for you. She smiles and leans into him.

No? What did you figure? INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- POKER TABLE -- NIGHT. Tanner’s chip stack has grown even more. And right now, h a got a fair pile in the middle. He has a five and six of clubs. On the flop we see a seve hearts, an eight of diamonds, and a nine of spades. Tanne flopped the straight. He tosses more chips in the pot, running everyone else of but -- A GIGANTIC, COMANCHE MAN in his 50’s. Sunglasses. The BIG MAN stares at the flop. Looks at Tanner. Tanner smiles. The BIG MAN calls him.  57. Fourth street: jack of Diamonds. Tanner throws five hundred in the pot.

Don’t chase me, chief. I’m already there. Mirrored shades stare back. ‘Chief’ didn’t sit well. He raises him 500. Tanner laughs and calls. The dealer tosses the river card: a five of diamonds. Tan knows he just got beat. So does the BIG MAN.

I check to the chief. Tanner’s eyes run cold. He stares at the BIG MAN. The BIG removes his glasses: five centuries of hate stare back. Tanner looks like he might kill this man right here. In f of everyone. And the BIG MAN looks ready for it. The dealer says possibly the worst thing he could at the absolute worst time:
Bet’s to you, sir. Tanner ignores him.
You Comanche? The BIG MAN nods.
Lords of the Plains.
Lords of nothing now. Beat.
I bet a thousand. Beat.
You can’t beat me.
I know.  58.
What if I raise? Tanner smiles an evil smile.
Be careful. The BIG MAN knows the raise was an apology. He also knows he raises, he’ll have to fight this lunatic for his life.
I call. The dealer lets an audible sigh of relief.
Show your cards, gentlemen. The BIG MAN turns over his flush.
What’s the Comanche word for warrior? The BIG MAN smiles.
Comanche. We are all warriors. Tanner nods. Stands.
I’m a warrior too.
Hope you fare better than we did.
Doing okay so far. Tanner grabs his chip trays and rises. The BIG MAN puts h sunglasses back on.
Know what Comanche means? It means ‘enemies forever’.
Enemies with who?
Everyone.  59. Tanner takes that in.
Know what that makes me?
An enemy.
No. Tanner leans across the table, inches from the BIG MAN’s face. Whispers like he’s telling him a secret.

It makes me a Comanche. Tanner looks into the mirrored shades, his own reflection staring back. He rises and walks away. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- BAR -- NIGHT. The hooker sits next to Toby now, pressing her bare leg against him. He isn’t used to women this attractive who a this aggressive. He teeters between wariness and fascinat
How old is he?
Fourteen.
Does he look like you?
I see his mama in him, everyone else sees me ... I don’t know.
He’s lucky if he does, I'll say that. She leans into him, her lips against his ear.
You staying in the hotel?

Take me to your room. He looks at her, knows he’s being worked. But it feels so good to have a woman next to him. It’s been so long.
Look, I’m, thank you, but ... I’m not here for me. As foolish as it sounds, he says it anyway:
I’m trying to do something noble for once, and -- She puts a finger to his lips, then lets that finger run his lip to his chest.
There’s no shame in needing the touch of a woman. She puts a hand to his cheek.
You need it, I know you do. How long has it been? (She is inches from his mouth) Let me touch you -- Something jerks her away. Toby looks up to find: Tanner h her by the arm.

Tryin’ to work my little brother, are you? As an astute judge of character, she knows instantly what kind of man she is now dealing with, and acts accordingly which is to say submissive and scared to death.
I wasn’t doing anything but --

But but but. You spied that stack of chips and saw an easy mark -- don’t get me wrong, no one likes a whore more than I do( he pulls her close), But those are my chips, you wanna try and steal from me? She shakes her head ‘no’.  61.
She wasn’t doin’ nothing. Tanner stares into the eyes of the terrified young woman.
Gonna get him in a room and what, call your pimp and roll him? Drug him, what?
Hey, come on --
No, I -- Tanner looks around the empty bar, still gripping the hooker’s arm.
Where is he? Where’s the man that holds your leash? No one in the bar fits the bill. The bartender watches th while pretending he isn’t.

Maybe we'll just sample the goods real quick. Tanner peals off a couple of hundreds from his wad, works hand up her dress, looking her in the eye, while he runs money inside her underwear. Toby stands up. Grabs Tanner’s arm and pulls it back.
Let her go.
(Into her ear) Merry Christmas. She steps back from both of them, turns, and hauls ass.
You're fucking crazy.
Call me!(whips Around to Toby) What are you doing?
How the fuck have you stayed out of prison for a year??  62. Big grin from Tanner.
It’s been a challenge (Sizes up his brother) Let’s go change it back then ... Fun’s all over now.
Not supposed to be fun.

Well you’re goddam makin’ sure of that. Tanner walks off. Toby scans the bar, exhales, then reluctantly follows. INT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- CHIP WINDOW -- NIGHT. They cash in their chips, now totalling twenty nine thous dollars.
You’1l need to fill out this tax form. Over twenty thousand, you have the option of receiving your money in a cashier’s check.
I'll take ten in cash. The rest in a check.
You want that made out to you?
No. First Texas Bank. She places a check in the check printer, hits a button, a voila -- money laundered. She hands the check and cash to Toby.
Let’s go to the room.
I think that’s one hell of an idea. Toby turns back and follows Tanner’s gaze to the pretty h clerk -- now in street clothes -- smiling at Tanner, and walking toward him.
Marcus wakes to a terrible pain in his upper chest. He si up. Reaches for a bottle of Tums on the night stand. Grab hand full.

Heart burn. I'll be fine. Marcus rises, goes to the sink. Gets a drink. The pain hi him. Tries to shake it off. Stares at himself, suffering the mirror. EXT. BEST WESTERN -- VERNON, TEXAS -- NIGHT. Marcus, dressed in his undershirt, jeans, and boots, step outside and walks toward the field behind the motel. He l out over the mesquites and cactus. The warm air helps. Or maybe its just the walk. He looks at the sky -- clouds and ten thousand stars carpet the ni An owl hoots. Flies over him. He watches the dark image m silently over him. Marcus walks toward a barbed wire fence, rests against it The warm air blows against him, pushing him like a tatter sail. Marcus looks to the stars as he leans into the wind tries to laugh off his suffering.
This is the thanks I get? Rotting from the inside out. After all I done for you... He looks out over the mesquites, who answer back in an an whistle as the wind whips through their leaves.
Toby brushes his teeth as Tanner lays in bed, the hotel c beside him, reading LORD OF THE PLAINS.
Boy, you Comanches were the real deal. (MORE )
(To Toby) You wanna hear what they did to the people they took captive?
No.
Damn right you don’t. Not a inch of mercy in them. (To the girl) You gonna show me any mercy, darlin’?
Not an inch.

You're right ... I’m gonna go see my boys tomorrow. Toby climbs into his bed and rolls away from Tanner and t clerk. Tanner clicks off the lamp. The clerk climbs on to him. Though she still wears her shirt, she is completely naked from the waist down. She presses her pelvis into hi she kisses him deeply.
I’m expecting a lot from you. Tanner presses into her and she moans.

What do you call that? Toby knows there will be no sleep with this a bed over. H sits up, pulls his jeans back on ... EXT. COMANCHE RED RIVER CASINO -- NIGHT. Toby walks through the parking lot, past semi’s and motor homes, toward the edge of the prairie. From here, it exte out forever. He walks through the grass, looking up at the same stars Marcus pondered. Looks back at the casino, its harsh neon lights violating the horizon. He turns back to the solace of the dark plains, and keeps walking ...  65. EXT. BEST WESTERN -- VERNON, TEXAS -- DAWN. Marcus sits in a cheap lawn chair in front of the motel, watching the sun come up over the highway. A few trucks blast by as he watches. The motel room door opens. PARKER stands in boxers and a shirt.
What’re you doing? Marcus talks without looking back at him.
Watching the sun rise. Sitting on a porch. Practicing for my future.
It’s a dangerous thing we do for a living. You’re lucky to have seen it through to the end. Hope I’m that lucky.
Without me by your side, I doubt you'll get close enough to a criminal to ever be in danger again. PARKER’s face clouds.
Just when I was staring to feel sorry for you. Marcus stands, and looks at PARKER for the first time.

Indians ain’t supposed to feel sorry for cowboys. It’s the other way around. PARKER looks into Marcus’s eyes, red and swollen from cry Marcus brushes past him and walks into the motel room. EXT. USED CAR LOT -- LAWTON, OKLAHOMA -- DAWN. We stare at the engine of a red Pontiac Grand Am as it re Toby is beneath it with a flashlight, studying. It is far early for anything legal to be happening on a used car lo  66.
Put it in gear. We hear it kick into drive. Toby stands up.
Sounds good. Let me give it a spin. Tanner gets out of the driver’s seat. Toby gets in and dr the Pontiac off. Standing across from Tanner is BUSTER ME 45, used car salesman in every sense.
We doing this one the same?
You got plates for it?
Ain’t got no more Texas plates. I got Arkansas, Kansas, New Mexico --
New Mexico works. Don’t report this stolen till Friday.
Friday, okay. Toby pulls back in.
How is it?
Runs good. Don’t like that it’s red.
He’s got New Mexico plates for it, though. Toby takes that in.
Okay.
We’re in business.  67. Buster walks off to start the paperwork. Tanner goes to t Blazer, grabs the duffel and the rifle cases, and tosses in the Grand Am.
You okay meeting the guy from Chevron by yourself?
You okay seeing Debbie by yourself?
I'll manage. Remember, this guy ain’t the enemy.
Oh, the oil man’s the enemy, make no mistake, he just ain’t ours.
I’ll be back to the ranch by dark.
I’ll be there.
(Points at the Grand Am) Arrest me red. You better drive like a school teacher. Toby climbs in the Blazer and drives off.

Marcus and PARKER sit at a table. The ceilings are easily twenty feet high, old cedar beams criss crossing it, ceil fans hanging down, circulating hot air. Through the large window, we see a FIRST TEXAS BANK. On the wall hangs a plaque dedicated to the soldiers from Coleman who have fought and died for this country. So man names, one would think the whole town died for our freedo
What’s the plan?
We’re gonna watch that bank like a deer feeder ...  68. Marcus scans the restaurant, looks out the front window a over the little square with almost no life in it.

This little town fits their bill, based on the ones they hit so far. Got a bank and not much else. So we'll just sit here and wait. In time we’ll be right. A waitress, she must be ninety years old, walks up.
Ya'll are a might early for lunch, ain’t you? It’s not even eleven.
Howdy ma’am. How are you today? She casts a mean glare at Marcus.
Hot. And not the good kind. What don’t you want?
Pardon?
What don’t you want?
Well, I was thinking I’d just get the --

I been working here forty-four years. Only thing anyone’s ever ordered is the T-Bone steak and a baked potato. ‘Cept some asshole from New York who tried to order trout in 1987. We don’t sell no goddam trout. Don’t have nuthin but T-bones. So, you either don’t want the corn on the cob, or you don’t want the green beans, so what don’t you want?
I don’t want green beans. She looks at PARKER.  69.
I don’t want green beans either.
Steaks cooked medium rare.
Could I have mine --
That weren't a question. Beat. WAITRESS (CONT’D) Tea for you boys to drink.
Tea’s great.
Yes ma’am. She storms off.

Tell you one thing. Ain’t no one robbing this son of a bitch ... My word. EXT. DEBBIE'S HOUSE -- CHILDRESS, TX -- DAY. DEBBIE HANSON, late 30's, quite the looker four kids ago, attempts to fold laundry while her 6 month old baby cries She surrenders to the screams and picks up the baby.

What? What? Are you wet? She checks. DEBBIE (CONT’D) Nope ... Your little gums hurt, that it? The doorbell chimes. She shakes her head in amazement at chaos of her life. She heads to the door. Opens it. Toby stands there. Anger washes over her face. DEBBIE (CONT’D) If you don’t have thirty five hundred dollars I’m calling the --  He holds up the cash.
What do you want? Toby looks at the baby.
Who's this?
One of the few mistakes in my life you're not responsible for. What do you want. Toby takes a minute to digest this.
It’s been that long since I’ve seen you?
What do you want.
Nothing. I’d like to say hi to the boys if I could. She motions to the money.
Do I want to know where that came from?
Not if you want to keep it. She almost smiles.
Come on in. 70. The place is modest on its very best day. But it is tidy. He does.
Put the money on the table and I’1l offer you a beer.
Mama died.  71. She turns.
When.
Last week.
Well, good riddance. No offense. Guess you'll be selling the ranch.
It goes to the boys. Debbie’s eyes light a bit.
Really?
It’s being put in a trust.
What’s that mean?
Means you can’t sell it. Those eyes turn dark.

Great. Something else I gotta take care of. Around the corner comes JUSTIN HANSON, 14, kind face of h father, wild eyes of his uncle. Built to play football. H rounds the corner. Freezes when he sees Toby.
(To Debbie) Give me two beers. EXT. DEBBIE'S HOUSE -- BACK PORCH -- DAY. Toby and Justin sit on shitty lawn chairs overlooking a y of weeds.
Where’s your brother?
Don’t know. A friend’s house I guess.  72.
How come you ain’t at school?
Don’t start for a week. Just two-a- days for football right now. Beat.
You should mow this lawn for your mama.
Ain’t got a lawn mower. It is awkward. Tense. Might as well get to it.
Your grandmother died. Beat.
Okay.
I’m giving the ranch to you and your brother. You remember going out there when you was little?
Yeah. What am I supposed to do with a ranch?
Anything but sell it. Toby leans close to Justin. Whispers in his ear.
We found oil on it. He let’s that sit.
You and Randy ain’t gonna have to worry about money no more. He looks at his boy.
You're gonna hear a lot of things about me ... And your uncle. (MORE )
Don’t be like us. Be smart. Look out for your brother. Justin nods.
Whatever I hear I won’t believe.

Believe it. Cuz I did all of it. Now you do it different. Don’t let your mother have any say in the money you boys get. She got a decent heart, but she can’t be trusted where money’s concerned ... If I’m not sitting here with you on Friday, tell her everything I just said, okay?
Okay. Toby looks at Justin’s full beer.
Ain’t gonna drink it? It’s okay.
You tell me not to be like you then you offer me a beer. Which is it? Toby smiles.

Good boy. He puts his hand on Justin’s shoulder. Justin Lets him. EXT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- DAY. Tanner sits on the front porch, twelve pack of Bud by his side. Empties litter the ground around him, though he isn drunk. He’s been immune to beer for decades. Across his lap is the AR 15 assault rifle. He has it most disassembled and is in the process of placing three penni behind the firing pin, making a semiautomatic rifle a mac gun. He reassembles the rifle and sets it by the scoped 30-06. Tanner picks up a rifle magazine and begins clicking roun into it from an army box of easily a thousand rounds.  74. On the table, we see another twenty rifle magazines, wait to be fed. As he loads, he sings an old Waylon Jennings s

head_text.subj: LONG AGO AND FAR AWAY. IN MY OLD

text: COMMON LABORER’S SHOES ... I TURNED

head_text.subj: THE WORLD ALL WHICH A WAY, JUST

text: He sets the loaded magazine down, and picks up another, begins loading, and sings the chorus:

head_text.subj: LET THE WORLD CALL ME A FOOL, BUT

text: IF THINGS AIN'T RIGHT ‘TWEEN ME AND YOU ... IT’S ALL THAT MATTERS AND I'LL DO ... ANYTHING YOU ASK ME TO. Tanner spots the Blazer driving up the dirt road. He walk out to meet it. Toby stops and gets out. Sees the rifles propped beside h
How were your boys? Toby points to the rifles.
What are you doing?

Insurance. If we can’t get enough from the branch in Jayton, we're gonna have to hit the one in Post. Post is a long way from home. The branch in Childress, well, can’t hit the branch there. For obvious reasons. And if you don’t want to hit the branch in Coleman ...
We can’t go back to the casino in Oklahoma now. Gotta head west, gotta be the one in New Mexico. Toby points to the rifles.
I don’t want all that shit in the car and we damn sure don’t need it. What if we get pulled over?  75.

We’re running two cars on the next one, brother. They’1l ride with me. You head to the casino in Riudoso and I’ll head north. They’re looking for two. No one robs a bank in separate cars ... It’s smart, Toby. Beat.
It is. But I still don’t like it.
It’s not to like, just to do. Toby points to the rifles.
We're not bringing them in the bank... Oil man come by?
They’re ready to go. When you pay that loan officer he’s gotta give you a form that shows a release of lien or something.
Okay.
You fax it over, and you’re done.
We gotta go meet the lawyer. Tanner downs his beer.

Waitin’ on you. EXT. RAYBURN LAW OFFICE -- SEYMOUR, TEXAS -- DAY. Tanner and Toby sit across from BILLY RAYBURN, 40'S, lawy handsome, and wearing the West Texas version of a suit: Jeans, blazer, and boots. Billy hands Toby a stack of papers.  76.
Initial in the boxes, and sign at the bottom. There’s three copies, gotta do the same to each.
And this makes you the executor.
It does.
So no matter what they charge us with, they can’t take it away.
There’s no way to trace funds from a casino. Once you get the checks to the bank, the trust is untouchable.
And you can’t tell nobody nuthin’, right?
What’s to tell? You boys won the money gambling, right? Tanner smiles.

Thirty two thousand pays off the reverse mortgage and those bastards paid the property taxes from 2007 to now, that’s another eleven thousand. Forty three thousand and you're free and clear. Have the loan officer fax me the lien release and I’1l get it over to the lease manager at Chevron. He hands Toby a business card.
Fax number’s on the card.
Okay.
How much you gonna make off this deal?  77.
Not near as much as I’m risking.
Then why do it? He looks at Tanner.
How long we known each other?
Since ... I don’t know. Always.

--. It’s the insult of it. That ranch is worth a half million without the oil, but they loaned the least they could get away with, just enough to keep your mama poor, on a guaranteed return. Thought they could swipe that land from you boys and suck on that oil for twenty five thousand dollars. It’s just so arrogant it makes my teeth hurt ... To watch you pay those bastards with their own money ... (He laughs at the thought) If that ain’t Texan I don’t know what is. Toby stands and offers his hand.
Thank you.
They can foreclose on Friday. Come hell or high water you be at the bank in Childress before they close Thursday. And knowing them fuckers, they’1l close early.
We'll be there. They rise to leave.

Toby. The trust needs to be managed by a bank ... You really wanna cover your tracks? Billy smiles.  78. EXT. T BONES CAFE -- COLEMAN, TEXAS -- DAY. The sun is setting as Marcus and PARKER sit on a bench un a Texas Porch that runs the length of the block.
All these little towns. Dying. What do you think’1l happen to ‘em?
This is your plan? Just sit here and see if this is the branch they rob next ... Marcus looks over at him.
Not much of a thinker, are you?
Do you want to live here? Old hardware store that charges twice what Home Depot does? One restaurant with a rattlesnake for a waitress? How are you supposed to make a living here?
People made a living here for a hundred and fifty years.
People lived in caves for a hundred thousand years, but don’t do it no more, and they’re the better for it. Beat.
Maybe your people did. Marcus smiles.

You're people did too. Long time ago, your ancestors was the Indians and someone else came along and killed ‘em or broke ‘em down and made you into one of them. A hundred and fifty years ago, all this was MY ancestors’ land. Everything you can see. (MORE )

Everything you saw yesterday. This was all Comancheria. Till the grandparents of all these folks took it. Now it’s being taken from them. Except it ain’t no army doing it. (PARKER points at the bank) It’s that son of a bitch, right there. Marcus studies his partner.
And here I am thinking you was slow as a two-legged turtle.
I may be. But that don’t make it any less true. Silence.
These boys should've hit this branch by now.
Then why are we still sitting here?
Just cuz ... I like this little town.
I know what you’re doing. You’re tryin’ to make this last as long as you can. Cuz the longer it lasts the farther you are from your front porch ... That ain’t fair --

To who? The bank? Only thing we can do is wait for these boys to make a mistake, and so far they ain’t. So relax. Enjoy this little town. From everything I see, it’ll die long before I do. They look out over the empty square, watching squirrels feasting underneath the pecan trees in the empty town squ as the sun dips below the horizon.
Toby and Tanner sit on the porch, staring at the stars as pack of coyotes whimpers and yips somewhere in the distan
Thinking about tomorrow?
Ain't you? Tanner shakes his head.
That little hotel clerk. Why’s it always the sweet ones that’s such devils when you get ‘em revved up?
I don’t know. Never been with a sweet one. Tanner laughs.
That's right. You like ‘em pissed off and looking for someone they can blame it on. Toby smiles.
Sure seems that way, don’t it?
This is a good thing you’re doing. You know that?
We're doing it. Tanner grins and winks.
Go easy on the tellers tomorrow, okay?
I’ll be as gentle as young nurse. Tanner stands up, stretches, and yawns.  81.
Wake me up at five.
Yep. Tanner disappears inside. Leaving Toby alone. He sits bac his mind running all the possibilities. How it can go rig How it can go wrong.

The crickets are chirping so loud, it echoes off the old, stone building. It doesn’t appear Marcus has moved in hou still staring out over the square. Across the way, PARKER carrying his suitcase into a motel. Marcus takes out his can of Copenhagen, packs it, and pla a pinch in his cheek. Ready for a long night of reflectio INT. HANSON RANCH HOUSE -- KITCHEN -- NIGHT. The wall clock says ten after five in the morning. Toby s dressed like a gang banger, pistol and three magazines fo on the table. He sips coffee as Tanner walks in dressed t same.

I’ll never understand how those gang bangers can walk around with their pants like this, dangling off their asses. No wonder they always get caught when they run from the police. Toby slides him a cup of coffee. Tanner sits. They drink their coffee in silence.
Want some breakfast? Tanner thinks that one over.
Yeah. Breakfast sounds good. Toby stands and heads to the fridge. Pulls out bacon and carton of eggs. Crosses over to the stove. Tanner watches brother as he cooks.  82.
Did you do this for mama?
Every morning. She didn’t eat much the last month.
Did you used to cook breakfast for your boys? Toby stops.
Yeah ... Been a long time, though. Tanner sits back in his chair, like a child, patiently waiting for his meal.
You do the bacon first, then the eggs in the grease, right?
Yep. That’s the way. Tanner watches his brother and sips his coffee as the bac begins to sizzle.

Two cars move toward us. The blazer and the Grand Am. Headlights on, though morning is breaking. They come clos Closer ... EXT. T BONES CAFE -- COLEMAN, TEXAS -- DAY. PARKER stands over us, looking down at something, shaking head in disbelief at -- Marcus, asleep on the bench, chin to his chest.
For someone who don’t want to spend his days sittin’ on his porch, you sure don’t mind lounging on everybody else’s.  83. Marcus stirs. Looks up at PARKER who hands him coffee ina Styrofoam cup..
Just ... Didn’t see the point in walking all the way to the motel just to walk back here in the morning.
Who’s not much of a thinker now? PARKER sits beside him.

Restaurant don’t open for another hour. And the two men begin their day where the last one ended, staring at the empty square. EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- JAYTON, TEXAS -- DAY. Toby and Tanner stand in front of the bank, ski masks on. They don’t move. Just stare straight ahead. We look over their shoulder and see why: The Jayton Branch is closed. Doors wrapped in chain and locked. Windows covered with large plywood boards.
Shit.
We gotta hit the branch in Post.
We won’t get there till after ten.
We don’t got a choice. Gotta have that money to the branch in Childress before they close tomorrow. Toby shakes his head as he pulls off his mask.
We don’t know Post. Don’t know the patterns of the folks out there.  84.

Pattern’s the same as it is everywhere. All these towns is dead. Post ain’t no different. Let's go. They turn and walk out of frame, leaving us to stare at t closed bank in a closed town. INT. T BONE’S CAFE -- DAY. Marcus and PARKER sit sipping coffee, looking over a map Texas.

First two banks were First Texas branches. There’s seven total: main branch in Fort Worth, and they ain’t messing with that. The branch in Olney they hit, the one in Archer City they hit, the one here, the one in Childress, Jayton --
That one’s closed.
Okay. That leaves the branch in Post. Childress is a decent sized town, I don’t think they’11 mess with that.
The branch in Vernon wasn’t First Texas and they hit that.
One of ‘em did. Alone. And then ran all the way across the square to get back to the car. I think his partner had no idea that was gonna happen.
What does that mean to us?
It means the only other First Texas branch that fits the bill is in Post.  85.
There’s plenty of little banks in other towns --
And they’d have robbed ‘em by now if they was interested in other banks, but they ain’t. They’re after First Texas’s money and that’s the only place they can get it that makes any sense.
It’s three hours away. If you wanna head that way we should get on the road. They both stand, Marcus tossing a twenty on the table.

Let’s get some troopers moving in that direction ... I’m feelin’ lucky. They move off toward the door, pushing it open, and flood the restaurant with the blinding Texas sun. EXT. STATE HIGHWAY 308 -- DAY. The Blazer and Grand Am drive through the ragged land bel the CAP ROCK: a geological marvel where the great plains plummet four hundred feet along a fault line, creating a cliff that dissects West Texas. On one side of the road is an endless wall of red dirt. O the other: land so broken it looks as though God stabbed repeatedly with two giant shovels, punishing it for some unknown offense. The cars breeze by us, the Cap Rock wall towering beside them. EXT. HIGHWAY 308 -- OUTSIDE POST, TEXAS -- DAY. Both vehicles pull off the road. Toby gets out of the Bla and jogs to the Grand Am. He gets in. The Pontiac pulls b on the road, past a sign that reads: POST - 3 MILES.  86. EXT. MAIN STREET -- POST, TEXAS -- DAY. There are actual signs of life here. A few cars in front the grocery store. Pick up trucks in front of the diner. and trucks at the gas station. The FIRST TEXAS BANK sign looms in the distance. INT. GRAND AM -- CONT.
This town looks busy.
Little bit. Look at the bank though. Not a car in front of it.
We do this quick.
Gotta take the hundreds this time.
Make sure they fan ‘em out in front of you. If an ink pack gets in the bag, that money’s useless.

Yep. They park in front of the bank. No other cars around. We watch from a distance as they get out and hurry inside, pulling on their masks. We DOLLY down a side street, now looking at the bank’s re wall. We CONTINUE until we are looking at First Texas Ban parking lot. Which is full. INT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- POST, TEXAS -- CONT. We stare at Toby and Tanner who stand frozen. We see what they see -- Two dozen people staring at them. Frozen as well. No one moves. No one knows what to do. Then it all happen a blur.

Tanner raises his pistol, pointing it frantically at everyone. All the people hit the deck. Toby is cemented to the plac where he stands. Tanner jumps the counter, pressing his gun hard to the fa of the teller.
Open the drawers! Every teller open their drawer and take three steps back. Tanner spots his brother not moving.
Toby snaps to, and covers the customers who are sitting a laying on the bank floor. Tanner begins grabbing the money himself from the teller drawers.
All of ya’1ll on your fucking knees. NOW. All the tellers drop to their knees.
A girl, in her twenties, laying on the floor, discreetly sending a text on her phone. It reads:

Tanner is frantically scraping money from the drawers, on after the other, when an old SECURITY GUARD comes around corner, his pistol raised. He cocks the hammer -- Tanner spins and fires round after round into him. He fal back as everyone screams. Another man stands and pulls a pistol from his boot, fire Toby and misses. Toby turns and fires while he ducks. They aren’t thirty f from each other, but the twisting and ducking is sending bullets into the wall, the ceiling, everywhere but their intended target.  88. Tanner takes aim and places a round in the side of the ma head, dropping him to a heap on the floor, like a jacket falling from a coat rack. Tanner leaps over counter.

Let's go! EXT. FIRST TEXAS BANK -- POST, TEXAS -- CONT. Toby and Tanner push through the doors and are met by a h of gunfire. The windows behind them shatter as they fire back and duc behind the Grand Am, which is taking a beating.

IT AIN'T. IT’S THE WHOLE FUCKING TOWN SHOOTIN’ AT US! Sure enough, across the road, hidden behind pickups, are locals with deer rifles, shotguns, whatever was in the gu rack when they heard shooting inside the bank. Tanner unl the passenger door, lays against the seat, and sticks the in the ignition. Cranks it to life. Folds the seat forwar

Get in. Toby dives in as the windows of the Pontiac shatter. Tann lays on the passenger seat, slams the car in reverse and his hand to press the gas pedal to the floor, his feet st hanging out the open door. The car races backwards as gunfire pulverizes the vehicle When the Pontiac is at a somewhat safer distance, we see disappear, the passenger door close, and the Grand Am is angrily around and slammed into drive, hauling ass down t street. Locals climb in their trucks to give chase. INT. GRAND AM -- CONT. Toby is panicking. Can't catch his breath. He’s hyperventilating. Tanner is as calm as he was at the poke table.  89.
Man, those concealed carry permits sure complicate a bank robbery, don’t they?
What are we gonna do??
Hey. We ain’t out of this, and I need you focused. Believe me when I say: this is where the rubber meets the road, little brother.
How are we gonna get away from this? You killed two people. At least.

And let me tell you something, we ain't through with that yet. You want to be anything but a black mark on your sons then I need you mountain lion mean, you understand me? Tanner looks in the rearview mirror and sees a half dozen pick ups and sedans coming up behind him.

Hold on. Tanner slams on the brakes. The Grand Am’s tires smoke an scream as the car comes to a stop in the middle of the ro EXT. GRAND AM -- HWY 308 -- CONT. Tanner walks to the trunk, unlocks it, takes out the AR 1 and walks down the center of the highway toward the oncom vehicles. He raises the rifle to his shoulder and sprays the vehicl with thirty bullets in less than a second. All the vehicles slam to a stop as bullets pound into the windshields, their hoods, their grills. The vehicles are instantly in reverse and beating a hasty retreat as Tanner drops the empty magazine, slams home another, and peppers the fleeing vehicles again. He turns and gets back in the Pontiac.  The door closes and the Pontiac speeds away. EXT. HWY 308 -- DAY. The Pontiac pulls along side the Blazer. Toby opens and gets out.
Needless to say, don’t take the highway back through Post. Head south. South, then west, got it?
We're done. Tanner looks over at him.

No we're not. Get to the Casino and change the money. Head north through New Mexico to the interstate. You take 287 back to Childress. Like we planned. Like you planned. This was your plan, and it’s worked every step of the way. Trust it.
Where are you headed? Tanner just smiles.

Don’t be stupid. You get the fuck out of here too. 90. the door Toby heads to the Blazer, unlocks the door, crams the mon under the seat, takes off his baggy jeans and baggy jacke revealing wranglers and a sweat drenched t shirt.
Hand those to me. He hands the baggy clothes to his brother. Tanner tosses in the back seat. Toby climbs in the Blazer.
Call me when you make it back to the ranch.
Hey ... I love you ... I mean that, Toby.  91. Toby stares at his brother, shocked by the words.
I love you too. Tanner winks and drives away. INT. GRAND AM -- DAY. Tanner smokes a cigarette, A soulless country-rock song blaring. he shuts the radio off.
Can’t nobody write a country song worth a shit no more. He begins singing one himself -- a VERY OLD TEX RITTER SO

text: As the cruisers approach, so does the dirt road. Tanner y the wheel, cutting in front of the cruisers, busting thro a barbed wire fence and spewing a rooster tail of dust as drives up the hill. The police cruisers give chase. In the distance, two more coming, headed by Marcus’s unmarked Crown Victoria. Tanner reaches the top of the hill, turns the car to face cruisers who are beginning to wind up the dirt road to hi  92. He pops the trunk, pulls out a satchel of rifle magazines his deer rifle, and a five gallon gas tank. He unscrews the top, crams the ski mask in the opening, a light it on fire.
